BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Since yesterday the weather has been warm. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2000 m.
Avalanches can sometimes be released easily and reach large size in isolated cases. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as on wind-loaded slopes above approximately 2100 m. From starting zones that have retained some snow in these regions the avalanches can in isolated cases still reach large size.
At low and intermediate altitudes moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Continuous warming to high altitudes.
The sleet gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Since yesterday the weather has been warm. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2000 m.
Avalanches can sometimes be released easily and reach large size in isolated cases. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as on wind-loaded slopes above approximately 2100 m. From starting zones that have retained some snow in these regions the avalanches can in isolated cases still reach large size.
At low and intermediate altitudes moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Continuous warming to high altitudes.
The sleet gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all regions large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Gliding avalanches can also occur. The wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Backcountry touring calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area. The snowpack will become gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area significant warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. As a consequence of warming during the day moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 3300 m. Medium-sized to large natural avalanches are still not entirely ruled out.

The danger of dry avalanches will decrease. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at elevated altitudes. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. 5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Wednesday. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

Several medium-sized dry and wet avalanches have been released on Thursday.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Until Sunday the weather will be very mild. On Saturday it will be very warm.
The surface of the snowpack will soften earlier than the day before. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. As a consequence of warming during the day moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 3300 m. Medium-sized to large natural avalanches are still not entirely ruled out.

The danger of dry avalanches will decrease. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at elevated altitudes. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. 5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Wednesday. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

Several medium-sized dry and wet avalanches have been released on Thursday.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Until Sunday the weather will be very mild. On Saturday it will be very warm.
The surface of the snowpack will soften earlier than the day before. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain large wind slabs formed. Dry avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases and reach large size. Below approximately 2300 m medium-sized to large ground avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall gave rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In addition the more recent wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions, but the avalanche danger will increase later. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible. From early morning the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m.
Avalanches can be released and reach large size in isolated cases, especially in high Alpine regions.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 1600 m rain has fallen in some regions. As a consequence of rising temperatures and rain up to intermediate altitudes the snowpack settled during the last few days.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The wind slabs of the last few days are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack on near-ridge shady slopes and in high Alpine regions.
Since Tuesday the weather has been mild. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften earlier than the day before, especially at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In addition the more recent wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions, but the avalanche danger will increase later. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible. From early morning the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m.
Avalanches can be released and reach large size in isolated cases, especially in high Alpine regions.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 1600 m rain has fallen in some regions. As a consequence of rising temperatures and rain up to intermediate altitudes the snowpack settled during the last few days.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The wind slabs of the last few days are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack on near-ridge shady slopes and in high Alpine regions.
Since Tuesday the weather has been mild. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften earlier than the day before, especially at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A critical avalanche situation will persist in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible.
New snow and wind slabs can be released and reach medium size, especially in high Alpine regions.
The current avalanche situation calls for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 3000 m.
Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach medium size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
Backcountry tours should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen in particular in the Prealps.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs formed. The wind slabs are lying on a crust in high Alpine regions.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 3000 m.
Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach medium size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
Backcountry tours should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen in particular in the Prealps.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs formed. The wind slabs are lying on a crust in high Alpine regions.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on steep sunny slopes at high altitude, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already soften in the late morning. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches as a consequence of warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On steep grassy slopes small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.

As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on sunny slopes, as well as on steep shady slopes also at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
The more recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. Further increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches as a consequence of warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can be released by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area. The snowpack will become gradually wet all the way through. On sunny slopes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area significant warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding avalanches are the main danger. Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.
The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Avalanches can release the wet old snow as well and reach large size in isolated cases. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.
The more recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers on very steep shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. Further increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches as a consequence of warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow are to be critically assessed.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase appreciably, especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in very isolated cases be released by people and reach medium size. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already soften in the late morning. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches as a consequence of warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The moist fresh snow of the last few days and the deep wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1900 m: In gullies and bowls mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack in shady places that are protected from the wind below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.
